Ethylene oligomerization over mesoporous FeNi-BTC catalysts: Effect of the textural properties of the catalyst on the reaction performance Nguyen Thi Kim Chau Conceptualization Methodology Data curation Validation Writing – original draft Young-Min Chung Conceptualization Methodology Resources Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition ⁎ Department of Chemical Engineering, Kunsan National University, 558 Daehak-ro, Kunsan, Jeollabuk-Do 54150, Republic of Korea Department of Chemical Engineering Kunsan National University 558 Daehak-ro Kunsan Jeollabuk-Do 54150 Republic of Korea Department of Chemical Engineering, Kunsan National University, 558 Daehak-ro, Kunsan, Jeollabuk-Do 54150, Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Mesoporous FeNi-1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylates (FeNi-BTCs) with different Fe/Ni ratios were prepared, and their catalytic activities in ethylene oligomerization were evaluated. The textural properties of the bimetallic FeNi-BTC were considerably affected by the Fe/Ni ratio, exhibiting a volcano relationship, with the maximum specific surface area, pore volume, and diameter observed at Fe/Ni = 10/90. The enhanced textural properties of the FeNi-BTC catalyst resulted in accelerated ethylene oligomerization and an increased C6–C8 oligomer selectivity. Using the Fe10Ni90-BTC catalyst, the rate of ethylene consumption and C6–C8 oligomer selectivity reached as high as 2823 g C2H4/g Ni h and 49%, which were approximately four- and two-fold higher than those of Ni-BTC, respectively. The remarkable reaction performance of the Fe10Ni90-BTC catalyst could be rationalized in terms of its well-defined mesoporous structure, which could decrease the mass transfer resistance and thereby facilitate intrapore ethylene diffusion during ethylene oligomerization. These results clearly demonstrate the potential of the FeNi-BTC catalyst in promoting ethylene oligomerization with a high activity and selectivity towards C6∼C8 oligomers. In the catalyst recycling study, whereas the catalytic activity decreased due to the partial deformation of the FeNi-BTC catalyst with repeated recycling, the selectivity towards C6+ oligomers gradually increased. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ethylene oligomerization FeNi-BTC Metal-organic frameworks Textural property Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Ethylene oligomerization is an efficient method of preparing oligomers with specific lengths that may be used in various petrochemical and fine chemical applications. Depending on their properties, such as carbon chain length and regioselectivity, oligomers may be used as versatile intermediates in the production of fuels, lubricants, surfactants, and polymers [1–3]. Although homogeneous ethylene oligomerization using a soluble metal-ligand complex as a catalyst has been extensively studied, the intrinsic problems of homogeneous systems, such as challenging catalyst separation, recycling, and unwanted polymer formation, remain unresolved [4–6]. Heterogeneous ethylene oligomerization in the presence of a solid catalyst is superior to homogeneous oligomerization in terms of catalyst separation and recycling, and thus, several studies have focused on designing an efficient heterogeneous catalyst for use in ethylene oligomerization. One strategy involves the formation of isolated single active sites (Ni, Cr, Fe, Co, etc.) on supporting materials, such as metal oxides [7,8], zeolites [9,10], aluminosilicates [11,12], and covalent organic frameworks (COFs) [13,14]. Among active metal candidates, Ni has been actively investigated because of its high activity and selectivity toward linear alkenes [12,15]. Espinoza et al. reported that light olefin selectivity strongly depended on the Ni concentration in Ni/SiO2-Al2O3, and increasing the Ni concentration improved the light olefin selectivity [16]. Finiels et al. reported that the pore size significantly affected catalyst deactivation, and very fast catalyst deactivation due to heavy reaction products blocking the pores was examined in ethylene oligomerization over a Ni catalyst supported on a microporous material. Meanwhile, the use of a Ni catalyst incorporated into a mesoporous material (Ni-MCM-41) was beneficial in increasing the carbon chain lengths of oligomers and alleviating catalyst deactivation caused by pore blocking [17]. Recently, Li et al. evaluated the catalytic activities of Ni-containing COFs with different pore sizes and demonstrated the critical roles of the textural properties of COFs on their catalytic performances [14]. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), which are highly ordered crystalline materials comprising metal nodes interconnected by organic ligands, may also be promising catalysts for use in ethylene oligomerization [18–20]. In addition to their high surface areas, several coordinatively unsaturated metal sites may be generated within the structures of MOFs via the removal of solvent molecules coordinated to the metal centers. The resulting isolated Lewis acid sites within the well-defined MOF structures may promote ethylene oligomerization, and thus, various MOFs have been used as heterogeneous Lewis acid catalysts in ethylene oligomerization [21–23]. Wang et al. reported ethylene tetramerization in the presence of a MIL-100(Fe) catalyst [24]. The evacuation temperature for activation, surface area, and Fe2+/Fe3+ ratio of MIL-100(Fe) were crucial in determining the product distribution. Farha et al. reported the preparation of a single-site Cr(III) catalyst supported on Nu-1000 and its reaction performance in ethylene oligomerization [25]. Despite its moderate oligomerization activity, the Cr-Nu-1000 catalyst exhibited a selectivity towards C8-C18 oligomers of up to 79%. The catalytic activity of an ultrathin Ni-based MOF nanosheet (Ni-UMOFN) catalyst in ethylene dimerization was also evaluated [26]. The five partially coordinated Ni centers formed via the termination of benzene-1,4-dicarboxylate ligands promoted dimerization with a high selectivity towards 1-butene of up to 92.8%. Another Ni-containing MOF, Ni-CFA-1, displayed a high activity (turnover frequency = 37100 h–1), with a 1-butene selectivity of 87.1% [18]. The authors insisted that isolated Ni sites within the MOF structure were responsible for the high stability of the catalyst during the reaction. Based on recent studies regarding heterogeneous ethylene oligomerization, a critical aspect of efficient catalyst design is clearly the formation of isolated active metal sites within well-defined, mesoporous supporting materials. Moreover, recent reports addressed that the incorporation of two different metals in a MOF structure can be considered as an efficient strategy for improving adsorption and catalytic activity [27–29]. In this context, herein, mesoporous FeNi-1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylates (FeNi-BTCs) with different Fe/Ni ratios were prepared, and their catalytic activities in ethylene oligomerization were evaluated. The bimetallic MOFs were selected because not only the concentrations of active Ni metal sites, but also the morphologies and textural properties, may be easily controlled by changing the Fe/Ni ratio. As will be discussed, the simultaneous incorporation of Fe and Ni metal nodes into the MOF structures considerably affected the textural properties of the FeNi-BTCs and thereby significantly influenced their catalytic performances in ethylene oligomerization. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (99.9%), FeSO4.7H2O (99%), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (1,3,5-H3BTC, 95%), modified methylaluminoxane (MMAO, 7 wt.% Al in toluene), 1-hexene (100%), and 1-octene (100%) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (St. Louis, MO, USA). 1-Decene (95%), 1-dodecene (95%), 1-tetradecene (95%), 1-hexadecene (90%), 1-octadecene (90%), and undecane (99%) were purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industry (Tokyo, Japan). N,N-Dimethylformamide (DMF, 99.8%) and toluene (99.8%) were supplied by Alfa Aesar (Haverhill, MA, USA), and ethanol (99.5%) was supplied by Samchun Chemical (Seoul, South Korea). All chemicals were used as received without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The catalysts were prepared via a solvothermal synthetic method under the same reaction conditions, and the organic ligand:metal molar ratio was fixed at 1:6. For Ni-BTC preparation, H3BTC (0.25 mmol) and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (1.5 mmol) were dissolved in DMF (30 mL) via stirring at ambient temperature for 30 min. The resultant homogeneous green solution was transferred to a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 423 K for 12 h. After natural cooling, the precipitate was centrifuged and washed three times each with DMF and then ethanol. Finally, the obtained samples were dried in a vacuum oven at 353 K for 24 h. Fe-BTC was prepared in the same manner, using FeSO4.7H2O (1.5 mmol) as the metal precursor instead of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O. To prepare the bimetallic FeNi-BTCs, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and FeSO4.7H2O were mixed with H3BTC in different molar ratios. The molar ratios of H3BTC/Fe2+/Ni2+ used were 1/0.3/5.7, 1/0.6/5.4, 1/1.2/4.8, and 1/1.8/4.2, resulting in the formation of Fe5Ni95-BTC, Fe10Ni90-BTC, Fe20Ni80-BTC, and Fe30Ni70-BTC, respectively. 2.3 Characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was performed using a high-resolution X-ray diffractometer (Empyrean, Malvern Panalytical, Malvern, UK) with Cu Kα (λ = 1.54 Å) radiation, and field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, SU8020, Hitachi, Tokyo, Japan) was performed to examine the changes in the morphologies of the as-prepared catalysts. The binding energies of Fe and Ni anchored on the BTC framework were analyzed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo VG Scientific MultiLab 2000, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA). Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) was performed using a Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (Nicolet iS50, Thermo Fisher Scientific) with a diffuse reflectance chamber (Pike Technologies, Madison, WI, USA) to investigate the chemical bonding of the FeNi-BTC catalysts. The specific surface areas, pore volumes, and pore diameters of the catalysts were determined via N2 adsorption at 77 K using a BELSORP-Max (MicrotracBEL, Japan). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted using an SDT 650 system (TA Instruments, New Castle, DE, USA) at a ramp rate of 10 K/min from room temperature to 1073 K, and the Fe and Ni contents of the MOFs were determined using inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, OPTIMA 7300 DV, PerkinElmer, Waltham, MA, USA). 2.4 Activity evaluation in ethylene oligomerization Ethylene oligomerization was performed using a high-pressure autoclave reactor (internal volume: 100 mL, 4560 series, Parr Instrument, Moline, IL, USA) connected to a high-pressure gas burette (internal volume: 1000 mL, Parr Instrument). In a typical run, 25 mg of catalyst was pre-activated at 393 K, MMAO was used as a co-catalyst (molar ratio Al/Ni = 100), and toluene was charged in the autoclave under an inert atmosphere. After purging with Ar three times, the reactor was pressurized with ethylene to 30 bar and heated to 333 K, and the mixture was vigorously stirred (1200 rpm) for 30 min using a magnetically driven impeller. During the reaction, the decrease in pressure in the gas burette was monitored and converted to the rate of ethylene consumption. Upon termination of the reaction by halting agitation, the reactor was disconnected from the gas burette and rapidly cooled in an ice bath. After quenching via the addition of 10% HCl in methanol, the used catalyst was filtered, and the organic layer of the solution was separated and filtered through a 0.2 μm polytetrafluoroethylene syringe filter. The separated solution (1 mL) was mixed with 0.1 mL undecane (external standard) and analyzed via gas chromatography (GC, 7890B, Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA, USA) with flame ionization detector (FID) using a Petrocol DH column (Sigma-Aldrich, 100 m × 0.25 mm I.D. × 0.5 μm film). The performance characteristics of the catalyst, such as activity and selectivity towards C4–C12 products, are quantified using the following equations: Activity ( g / g Ni . h ) = Mass of the consumed ethylene ( g ) Mass of active site Ni ( g ) Time ( h ) Selectivity , S i ( wt . % ) = Mass of compound i Mass of all compounds 100 ( whereas i = C 4 ; 1 − C 4 ; … ; C 12 , 1 − C 12 ) A recycling study was performed by replenishing the MMAO to evaluate the reusability of the FeNi-BTC catalyst, e.g., after the first reaction using a fresh catalyst was completed, the reactor was cooled, disconnected from the gas burette, depressurized, and purged with Ar. After a small amount of the reaction solution (2.5 mL) was withdrawn for GC analysis, the same procedure used in the activity study was applied, including replenishment of the MMAO for the next run. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst preparation and characterization Fe-BTC, Ni-BTC, and bimetallic FeNi-BTC with different Fe/Ni ratios were prepared using a facile one-step solvothermal method [30]. Fig. 1 (a)–(f) show the changes in the color and morphology of bimetallic FeNi-BTC with respect to the Fe/Ni ratio. As the Fe content increases, the color of FeNi-BTC gradually changes from light green (Ni-BTC) to dark red (Fe-BTC). The morphology of the catalyst is significantly affected by the Fe/Ni ratio. Unlike Ni-BTC, which displays a flower-like morphology comprising numerous nanosheets, Fe-BTC exhibits a granule-shard morphology. The morphologies of the FeNi-BTCs change from flower-like nanosheets to granules as the Fe content increases, indicating the successful incorporation of Fe within the Ni-BTC structures. Moreover, energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping reveals uniform distributions of Fe, Ni, C, and O in Fe10Ni90-BTC (Fig. 1 (g)). The PXRD patterns of the Ni-BTC, Fe-BTC, and FeNi-BTC catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 (a). The PXRD pattern of Ni-BTC exhibits characteristic broad diffraction peaks at 2θ = 11.6°, 20.8°, 22.3°, 23.8°, and 33.5°, corresponding to the (110), (151), (101), (024), and (025) planes, respectively [30,31]. The highly connected hierarchical micro- and mesoporous structures of Ni-BTC are responsible for its low crystallinity. The 2θ positions of the peaks in the PXRD pattern of Fe-BTC are consistent with those in the PXRD pattern of MIL-100(Fe) [32]. In the PXRD patterns of the FeNi-BTCs, the characteristic peaks representing Ni-BTC (marked by #) and Fe-BTC (marked by *) are observed, which indicates that Ni and Fe ions are incorporated into the BTC frameworks. The intensities of these peaks gradually decrease as the Fe content increases, suggesting that the crystallinity of FeNi-BTC depends strongly on the Fe/Ni ratio. In the DRIFT spectra, the characteristic diffuse reflectance signals contributed by the Fe/Ni metal nodes and the H3BTC linker were examined, as shown in Fig. 2 (b). The broad bands ranging from 3000 to 3700 cm−1 may be ascribed to the stretching of the –OH groups of water molecules adsorbed on the surfaces of the samples [30]. In the spectra of Ni-BTC, Fe-BTC, and the FeNi-BTCs, the ν(COOH) peak at approximately 1721 cm–1 is not observed. New bands are observed in the regions 1624–1569 and 1440–1369 cm–1, which are attributed to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of the carboxylate groups (COO–), respectively [30,31]. The new reflectance peaks at approximately 751–868 cm–1 indicate the existence of the C–H stretching vibration mode inside the benzene ring. The peak at 578 cm–1 is associated with the vibration of coordination bonds between the metal atoms and the carboxylic groups, manifesting the existence of metal-oxygen (Fe/Ni–O) bonds in the bimetallic Fe/Ni–MOFs structure. These results indicate that Ni and/or Fe ions are successfully coordinated to the H3BTC linkers [33,34]. The textural properties of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 (c)–(d) and Table 1 . As shown in Fig. 2 (c), all samples exhibit typical type IV N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms with hysteresis loops in the relative pressure (P/P0) range 0.4–0.9, indicating the presence of mesoporous structures. The Fe/Ni ratio significantly influences the textural properties of the FeNi-BTCs. As shown in Table 1, whereas monometallic Fe- and Ni-BTCs display small surface areas, the simultaneous use of Fe and Ni as metal nodes results in a considerable increase in the surface area. The enhanced textural properties may be resulted from the creation of new mesopores attributed to the existence of two different metals in the MOF structure [35–37]. A volcano relationship is observed between the surface area and Fe/Ni ratio, and the surface area of Fe10Ni90-BTC reaches as high as 449.7 m2/g, which is approximately 11.6- and 5.2-fold higher than those of the Fe- and Ni-BTCs, respectively. The Fe/Ni ratio also significantly affects the pore diameter and volume of the FeNi-BTC. XPS was conducted to investigate the chemical compositions of monometallic Fe-BTC and Ni-BTC and the bimetallic FeNi-BTCs. As shown in Fig. 3 , Fe 2p, Ni 2p, C 1s, and O 1s peaks are observed in the XP survey spectra of the bimetallic FeNi-BTCs. The characteristic Fe 2p3/2 (∼711.5 eV) and Fe 2p1/2 (∼725.2 eV) peaks, and associated shake-up satellite peaks at 716.9 eV, as shown in Fig. 3 (a), indicate the presence of Fe3+ ions in Fe-BTC and FeNi-BTC [34]. The shifts of the Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 peaks to lower binding energies in the spectra of the Fe5Ni95- and Fe10Ni90-BTCs suggest that the electronic properties of the Fe3+ ions may be affected by the abundant Ni2+ ions around them [34,38]. However, the peak positions in the spectra of the Fe20Ni80- and Fe30Ni70-BTCs are similar to those in the spectrum of Fe-BTC, indicating that the interaction between Fe3+ and Ni2+ via the oxygen atoms of BTC linkers weakens as the Fe content increases. The dependence of the interaction between the two metal ions on the Fe/Ni ratio is also confirmed by the Ni 2p XP spectra. These spectra display peaks representing Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 at ∼855.7 and ∼873.5 V, respectively, with two shake-up satellite peaks (∼862.7 and 881.9 eV), suggesting the presence of Ni2+ in the FeNi-BTCs (Fig. 3 (b)) [30,38]. In contrast to the Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 peaks, the Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 peaks shift to higher binding energies as the Fe content increases to >20% in FeNi-BTC. These shifts suggest that electrons are partially transferred between the Fe and Ni ions via the bridging oxygen atoms of the H3BTC linkers, suggesting the coexistence of Fe and Ni in the MOF network [38,39]. Moreover, the proportional changes in the intensities of the Fe 2p and Ni 2p peaks relative to the Fe and Ni contents also suggest the quantitative incorporation of Fe and Ni as metal nodes within FeNi-BTC, as confirmed using ICP-OES (Table 1). The deconvoluted C 1s XP spectra shown in Fig. 3 (c) may be assigned to C=C (283.8 eV), C–C (285.3 eV), C–O– (286.7 eV), and C=O (289.2 eV) bonds [34,38–40]. The O 1s spectra display three peaks with binding energies of 529.0, 531.3, and 532.8 eV, corresponding to COO–, Ni/Fe–O–, and C–O, respectively (Fig. 3 (d)) [38–40]. TGA was performed to assess the thermal stabilities of the Ni-BTC and Fe10Ni90-BTC catalysts. As shown in Fig. S1, mass losses are observed in three temperature ranges: <400, 400–573, and 573–773 K. The first and second mass losses reveal the removal of the physically adsorbed and intercrystalline water and DMF from the cavities of the sample [30,41]. The third mass loss is due to the thermal decomposition of the H3BTC ligand, which terminates at >773 K, indicating the complete decomposition of the organic matter. However, the TGA thermograms suggest that the Ni-BTC and Fe10Ni90-BTC catalysts are stable at the reaction temperature. 3.2 Catalytic performance in ethylene oligomerization Ethylene oligomerization was performed in the presence of the monometallic Fe-BTC and Ni-BTC and bimetallic FeNi-BTC catalysts with MMAO as the activator, and the results are shown in Table 2 . C4–C12 oligomers are produced using all catalysts except Fe-BTC, and neither C14+ oligomers nor polymers are formed in the catalytic reactions (Fig. S2). Fe-BTC does not promote oligomerization, and Ni-BTC exhibits a moderate catalytic performance. Wang and co-workers reported that the surface area and the Fe2+/Fe3+ ratio of coordinatively unsaturated sites (CUS) of MIL-100(Fe) catalyst were important in promoting ethylene oligomerization [24]. In this context, the inactivity of Fe-BTC might be ascribed to its poor textural properties. It seems that only limited number of active sites, CUS, existed in the Fe-BTC structure, and they were hardly accessible during a reaction. However, the activity is considerably enhanced in the presence of the bimetallic FeNi-BTC catalysts. As shown in Fig. 4 , the initial reaction rate and total ethylene consumption are significantly affected by the Fe/Ni ratio of the catalyst. The activity increases in the order Fe-BTC < Ni-BTC < Fe30Ni70-BTC < Fe5Ni95-BTC < Fe20Ni80-BTC < Fe10Ni90-BTC. In addition to the activity, the product distribution also changes with respect to the Fe/Ni ratio of FeNi-BTC. In the presence of the FeNi-BTC catalyst, the activity and selectivity towards C6+ oligomers increase, whereas selectivity towards C4 oligomers decreases. Compared to those of the Ni-BTC catalyst, the C6 and C8 selectivities of Fe10Ni90-BTC increase by 76% and 198%, respectively (Entry 3, Table 2). This suggests that the addition of ethylene to the preformed C4 and C6 oligomers is further accelerated compared to the first ethylene dimerization when using the Fe10Ni90-BTC catalyst. In Table S1, the reaction performance of the Fe10Ni90-BTC catalyst was compared with those of previously reported MOF catalysts. While it was difficult to compare the catalytic activities directly because the results were obtained in the presence of different metal-containing MOFs under different reaction conditions, both the activity and C6/C8 selectivity of Fe10Ni90-BTC catalyst were comparable to those of other catalysts. Figs. 5 and S3 show the changes in the textural properties of the FeNi-BTC catalyst according to the Fe/Ni ratio and the effect of the altered textural properties on the catalytic performance in ethylene oligomerization. Volcano relationships between the Fe/Ni ratios and textural properties of the FeNi-BTCs are apparent, with the maximum specific surface area (Fig. 5 (a)) and pore diameter (Fig. S3 (a)) and volume (Fig. S3 (b)) observed at Fe/Ni = 10/90. The order of the ethylene oligomerization activities of the catalysts is consistent with that of the textural properties, suggesting that the improved pore structure of the FeNi-BTC catalyst accelerates ethylene oligomerization. Moreover, the textural properties of the catalyst display a crucial influence on the product distribution. More C6 and C8 oligomers are obtained via ethylene oligomerization using an FeNi-BTC catalyst with further improved textural properties, as shown in Figs. 5 (b) and S3 (c)-(d). Therefore, the mesoporous FeNi-BTC catalyst structure is clearly more efficient in accelerating the tri- and tetramerization of ethylene. The highest activity and C6–C8 oligomer selectivity are observed for ethylene oligomerization over the Fe10Ni90-BTC catalyst. The mesoporous structure (∼18 nm) with a large pore volume (1.2 cm3/g) enables the more efficient approach of dimers and/or trimers, in addition to ethylene, towards the active sites. Notably, the proportional increase in the amount of linear alpha olefin among the reaction products in accordance with the enhanced mesoporosity of the catalyst also suggests the significance of pore space in facilitating propagation. The modified electronic properties of FeNi-BTC catalyst by the existence of two different metal nodes also affected the reaction performance. As discussed with XPS in Fig. 3, electrons can be transferred between Fe and Ni ions via oxygen atoms of BTC linkers, and the electron density of Ni might be increased due to the higher electronegativity of Ni (χ = 1.91) compared to that of Fe (χ = 1.83). The easier product desorption by the enhanced electron density of Ni is beneficial in suppressing undesirable hydrocarbon deposition on the active sites during a reaction [4,42]. Ethylene oligomerization over the FeNi-BTC catalyst may be understood in terms of the Cossee-Arlman mechanism, as shown in Fig. 6 [14]. From a mechanistic perspective, the empty d orbital of a Ni metal node on FeNi-BTC is considered an active site where olefin coordination-insertion, β-hydride (β-H) elimination, and the formation of metal alkyl and metal hydride intermediates should successively occur. The catalytic cycle is initiated by alkyl transfer from the Al-alkyl (MMAO activator) to the Ni active site, which results in the formation of a Ni site with a vacancy where ethylene may be coordinated. Chain growth occurs via ethylene insertion, and β-H elimination of the longer Ni-alkyl leads to oligomer formation. The regeneration of the Ni–H intermediate during the first catalytic cycle enables the initiation of the second cycle via ethylene insertion to form a Ni-alkyl intermediate. Moreover, additional isomerization and propagation result in the formation of higher and/or branched olefins [43,44]. To investigate the dependences of the catalytic activity and product distribution on the reaction parameters, ethylene oligomerization was performed in the presence of the Fe10Ni90-BTC catalyst under various reaction conditions. As shown in Fig. 7 , the reaction is significantly affected by the reaction parameters. When the reaction temperature is increased from 293 to 313 K, the rate of ethylene consumption is approximately doubled. However, the reaction rate decreases as the reaction temperature is increased to >313 K, and is sharply reduced to approximately 29% of the activity observed at 293 K (Fig. 7 (a), (d)). Whereas reaction rates may generally accelerate with increasing reaction temperature, this reaction rate decreases, possibly due to the retarded transportation of ethylene to the active sites caused by the reduced solubility of ethylene as the temperature increases. However, the increased selectivity towards higher oligomers in proportion to the reaction temperature indicates that chain growth may be facilitated at a higher temperature. Fig. 7 (b) and (e) show the effect of ethylene pressure on the catalytic performance. Clearly, oligomerization under a higher ethylene pressure promotes the more efficient supply of ethylene to the active sites, thereby accelerating the reaction and increasing the degrees of tri- and tetramerization of ethylene. The activator-to-active-metal (Al/Ni) ratio is also critical in promoting ethylene oligomerization. As the Al/Ni molar ratio increases from 100 to 300, the activity of the Fe10Ni90-BTC catalyst is enhanced from 2823 to 4750 g C2H4/g Ni h. Whereas the C6–C8 oligomer selectivity also increases, the alpha olefin selectivity decreases as the Al/Ni molar ratio increases (Fig. 7 (c) and (f)). This suggests that increasing the amount of MMAO accelerates the olefin shift reaction and isomerization. 3.3 Catalyst recycling study To evaluate the reusability of the Fe10Ni90-BTC catalyst, three recycling runs were conducted by replenishing the MMAO in each run. As shown in Figs. 8 and S4, sharp reductions in the reaction rate and total ethylene consumption are observed as the reaction is repeated, indicating the poor recyclability of the Fe10Ni90-BTC catalyst under the reaction conditions. However, the changes in the product distribution over the recycling study are remarkable, e.g., although the rate of ethylene consumption decreases significantly, the selectivity towards higher olefins (C6+) gradually increases as recycling is repeated. This suggests that the initial rate of ethylene dimerization is reduced more than that of the subsequent oligomerization between ethylene and the preformed oligomers. Therefore, pore-blocking by the oligomerized products is not severe and does not induce catalyst deactivation. To examine the cause of catalyst deactivation, the changes in the textural and structural properties of the Fe10Ni90-BTC catalyst were examined after the recycling study. As shown in Fig. 9 , significant changes in the textural properties and crystallinity of the Fe10Ni90-BTC catalyst occur during the recycling study. The significant decrease in the surface area from 449.7 to 103.4 (1st recycle) and 31.2 m2/g (3rd recycle), in particular, clearly indicates that the porous Fe10Ni90-BTC structure collapses severely during the recycling study (Table S2). The detection of small amounts of Fe (0.07 wt.%) and Ni (0.26 wt.%) in the ICP analysis of the reaction solution after the first recycle test confirms that these metals were leached out during the recycle run. The result implies that both the structural deformation and the active metal leaching of Fe10Ni90-BTC catalyst during a reaction are responsible for the catalyst deactivation. It should be noted that the MMAO itself has little impact on the structural deformation of catalyst. As presented in Fig. 9 and Table S2, there were little changes in the textural properties and crystallinity of Fe10Ni90-BTC catalyst recovered from the first recycle test conducted in the absence of ethylene. TGA of the used catalyst was also performed to examine whether any oligomers remained within the pores (blocking the pores) but identifying any difference between the thermograms of the fresh and used catalysts was challenging. Based on these results, the structure of the Fe10Ni90-BTC catalyst is unstable under the reaction conditions, and the deformation of the pore structure may cause catalyst deactivation. 4 Conclusion In this study, ethylene oligomerization was performed using the FeNi-BTC catalysts with different Fe/Ni ratios. The textural properties of the bimetallic FeNi-BTC catalyst significantly depended on the Fe/Ni ratio, exhibiting a volcano-shaped dependence with the maximum specific surface area and pore diameter and volume observed at Fe/Ni = 10/90. The highest rate of ethylene consumption and selectivity towards C6–C8 oligomers were obtained using the Fe10Ni90-BTC catalyst, which suggests that the large, well-defined mesoporous structure of this catalyst may be superior in alleviating mass transfer resistance during ethylene oligomerization. However, the pore structure of the Fe10Ni90-BTC catalyst collapsed during recycling, resulting in a sharp reduction in the rate of ethylene consumption. Nevertheless, the enhanced selectivity towards higher olefins (C6+) suggested that the initial rate of ethylene dimerization was reduced more than those of sequential tri- and tetramerization as catalyst recycling was repeated. coredata.dc:description: Mesoporous FeNi-1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylates (FeNi-BTCs) with different Fe/Ni ratios were prepared, and their catalytic activities in ethylene oligomerization were evaluated. The textural properties of the bimetallic FeNi-BTC were considerably affected by the Fe/Ni ratio, exhibiting a volcano relationship, with the maximum specific surface area, pore volume, and diameter observed at Fe/Ni = 10/90. The enhanced textural properties of the FeNi-BTC catalyst resulted in accelerated ethylene oligomerization and an increased C6–C8 oligomer selectivity. Using the Fe10Ni90-BTC catalyst, the rate of ethylene consumption and C6–C8 oligomer selectivity reached as high as 2823 g C2H4/g Ni h and 49%, which were approximately four- and two-fold higher than those of Ni-BTC, respectively. The remarkable reaction performance of the Fe10Ni90-BTC catalyst could be rationalized in terms of its well-defined mesoporous structure, which could decrease the mass transfer resistance and thereby facilitate intrapore ethylene diffusion during ethylene oligomerization. These results clearly demonstrate the potential of the FeNi-BTC catalyst in promoting ethylene oligomerization with a high activity and selectivity towards C6∼C8 oligomers. In the catalyst recycling study, whereas the catalytic activity decreased due to the partial deformation of the FeNi-BTC catalyst with repeated recycling, the selectivity towards C6+ oligomers gradually increased.
coredata.dc:title: Ethylene oligomerization over mesoporous FeNi-BTC catalysts: Effect of the textural properties of the catalyst on the reaction performance
